abstracts.cdata!:
Although the project is assessed as
            satisfactory, sustainability is uncertain, in view that the
            non-formal education program may be influenced by the
            proposed government decentralization, and further hampered
            by the absence of local governments' commitment
            responsiveness. Key lessons re-emphasize the need for simple
            project design criteria in the absence of strong local
            capacity, and political instability, since project design
            was weakened by inadequate institutional analysis, and by
            the lack of clearly defined objectives, with measurable
            performance, and development indicators. Government
            assurances of sustained support at the national level,
            throughout longstanding project implementation, may not be
            sufficient for operations such as this one, whose focus was
            on local activities; rather community, and beneficiary
            involvement, with support by local authorities, should
            remain critical to ensure sustainability. Hence,
            implementation responsibilities need to be clearly defined
            during project design, with adequate delegation of authority
            to ensure a focused, and flexible process. Similarly,
            incentives - such as salaries, and allowances - should be
            specified, payable to staff, as well as teachers, to ensure
            their commitment.
